La Hague is an impressive and very important facility – it plays a key role in reprocessing spent nuclear fuel and recovering valuable materials. Don’t take this as pure fact, but as I have understood it, France and many other countries do not yet have a permanent geological disposal site for the high-level waste that remains after reprocessing.
In contrast, Finland is building Onkalo, the world’s first operational deep geological repository for spent nuclear fuel, located at Olkiluoto. While France leads in reprocessing, Finland is pioneering permanent geological disposal. Both approaches are essential parts of the global nuclear waste management picture.

Ironically the biggest opposition for nuclear energy are the anti -fossil fuel crowd.

New fuel is cheaper and people/governments are paranoid about nuclear proliferation.

The first issue has several solutions: store all the spent fuel until new fuel becomes more expensive than reprocessing (so the spent fuel is a valuable long-term investment), subsidize reprocessing to effectively mandate all spent fuel is reprocessed, or switch to fast-breeder reactor designs configured with molten salt reactors with continuous reprocessing of the fuel matrix. (the latter has the problem of maximum nuclear proliferation paranoia, albeit somewhat less so for hypothetical thorium-uranium cycle reactors instead of uranium-plutonium)

France is the only country in the world to use the section option (mandate reprocessing and heavily subsidize it). This approach also makes it more economical and much, much more strategically secure (full self sufficiency, no reliance or dependency on importing fuel from Uranium-rich countries), even if it still costs somewhat more than buying new fuel. France did it both because of their nuclear weapons program and for national security power interests. (they way they managed their nuclear power plant construction program is also exceptional given the tight regulation, high degree of standardization, and resulting safety records)


Of course, the real problem is that most of the mismanaged waste isn't unprocessed spent fuel, but large volumes of contaminated material that need to be processed, treated, condensed, and then disposed of properly (for any remaining residue). That's the kind of stuff that's supposed to be in the iconic yellow barrels. (though given the gross corruption and mismanagement ... and lack of proper oversight, that led to the sort of dumping in the case of the German salt mine ... I wouldn't want to bet on the levels of contamination for some of that stuff)

Spent fuel itself is generally too valueable to store as simple waste, even if it's not valueable enough to fully  reprocess (yet), but worth keeping around as a useful raw material. Plus you have to let it sit for years before it's safe to reprocess, anyway. But, from the reprocessing also comes the extraction of the fission product, particularly the medium-term (ie decades to hundreds of years) isotopes like Strontium 90 and Cesium 137. Those can be rendered chemically inert by dissolving into glass (forming silicates, given both of those have many, many soluble salts, especially Cesium, like all alkali metals) and going to a long term geologic repository (there's a tiny amount relative to the power produced, so this isn't a big deal ... as long as you have remotely sane regulation, and any sort of sane long-term planning, from a business perspective, too, since improper dumping is never good for long-term profits ... it just depends how long term you think)

But, even with the fission products, there's valueable use of them as well, and potential for nuclear-thermal generators of various types ... just don't distribute them throughout the wilderness and then abandon them like the Soviets did. (more realistically, they could be used as secondary generator fuel on-site with some power plant models ... and all sorts of waste processing is better to do on-site as much as possible as well, both for security/risk reasons, and sheer cost effectiveness)

Fast reactors also burn up a small portion of fission products due to the high neutron flux (or the side effects of high neutron flux), and fast-breeder reactors tackle that while also extending the refueling cycle dramatically. (assuming all bred fuel is intended for power generation with no reprocessing into weapons material, the fuel cycle can be much longer, or indefinite in a molten salt reactor, since the molten salt fuel matrix can be continually reprocessed during operation) But the most promising of these types are still experimental for the most part, and there hasn't been enough public interest, support, or funding to really make them a reality. (so the safest, best tested, most reliable designs are mostly derivatives of conventional tried and true light water reactors, many descending from the already mature designs the French licensed from the US in the first place)

Spent fuel is not reprocessed for one reason. It is cheaper for reactors to use U-235 from mining. 
Now let's talk about reprocessing. It is by far the dirtiest, most dangerous process for nuclear workers. It is also the most polluting process.  It is very expensive and only reclaims 1-2% of the spent fuel for reuse as plutonium and U-235. The rest is still nuclear waste. Once the reprocessed fuel is reused once, it is again... wait for it, nuclear waste. La Hague and Sellafield were the only reprocessing plants in Europe. They have managed to make the Atlantic Ocean all the way to the Arctic Circle the most radioactively contaminated ocean in the world. Sellafield was shut down. The British government estimates that it will cost $1 billion a year just to maintain the site and at least 100 years to clean it up at God only knows what cost. La Hague no longer has any international customers and only reprocesses for its parent company, Orano, which has been taken over by the French government to keep it from going bankrupt. Pity the poor French taxpayer.
Russia has 2 reprocessor on barges that cost exorbitant sums and very lengthy times to start up. Their performance has been very disappointing and they run at less than 30% efficiency. In addition,  it poses conventional and radiation hazards to people and the environment.  So, unless we are looking to build nuclear bombs, we are better off as a society to put the spent fuel away in safe underground repositories where this valuable resource will be available to future generations once technology catches up.

Nuclear Waste is Recyclable: Up to 96% of spent nuclear fuel is recyclable, containing over 90% of its original energy.
France Leads in Recycling: France has the highest share of nuclear power globally and operates the largest nuclear recycling plant, run by Orano.
Orano's Recycling Process:
Spent fuel rods arrive in heavily shielded 110-ton casks.
Rods are stored in pools for 5-7 years to cool down.
A chemical process separates uranium, plutonium, and fission products.
Uranium can be reused in reactors.
Plutonium is mixed with uranium to create MOX fuel, used in reactors, generating 10% of France's electricity.
Fission products (4% of waste) are vitrified (trapped in glass) and stored, awaiting a permanent storage site.
Challenges of Recycling:
Cost: Recycling is more expensive than using new uranium, which is currently abundant.
Plutonium Proliferation: The process produces purified plutonium, a key component in nuclear weapons, raising proliferation concerns. This is a major reason why the US stopped reprocessing in the 1970s.
Technical Complexity: The recycling process is complex and not widely available.
Waste Generation: Recycling generates other waste from chemicals and equipment used.
MOX Fuel: Once-recycled MOX fuel isn't currently recycled again, eventually becoming waste.
Global Recycling Efforts:
France is the leader.
Russia recycles about a tenth of what France does.
India recycles and plans to expand.
China has a demonstration plant and is building more.
The UK stopped due to cost.
Japan has faced massive delays and cost increases in building a plant.
France's Strategy:
France chose to recycle 60+ years ago for energy independence, as nuclear power is crucial to their electricity supply.
Recycling operations and nuclear power plants are state-owned.
France is recycling more than it reuses, storing extra uranium for potential future use.
Alternative Recycling Methods:
Pyroprocessing is a newer method being researched that uses molten salt, produces less pure plutonium (reducing proliferation risk), but is still in the lab phase.
Conclusion:
Recycling is technically feasible and reduces high-level waste volume.
High costs and proliferation risks are major deterrents.
Recycling may make sense for countries prioritizing nuclear power and energy independence, but it doesn't eliminate the need for long-term waste storage.
New, cheaper technologies may emerge, but don't seem imminent.

Nuclear fuel rods are stored in steel-lined concrete pools surrounded by water. The water in a fuel pool is usually between 25°C and 35°C, and every 7 centimeters of water cuts the amount of radiation in half. 

Nuclear fuel rods become more radioactive as they are used in a reactor. A fresh rod of low enriched uranium pellets can be safely handled with gloved hands, but after a year or two of use, it becomes highly radioactive and unsafe to approach without many feet of water shielding. 

When the pools loose their water the fuel’s Zirconium coating self ignites when in contact with air, like Sodium. These fires are thermal runaway like Lithium batteries and are extremely hot and near impossible to quench.

A fire from spent fuel stored at a U.S. nuclear power plant could have catastrophic consequences, according to new simulations of such an event.
A major fire "could dwarf the horrific consequences of the Fukushima accident," says Edwin Lyman, a physicist at the Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit in Washington, D.C. 


“We're talking about trillion-dollar consequences," says Frank von Hippel, a nuclear security expert at Princeton University, who teamed with Princeton's Michael Schoeppner on the modeling exercise.
The revelations come on the heels of a report last week from the U.S. National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine on the aftermath of the 11 March 2011 earthquake and tsunami in northern Japan. The report details how a spent fuel fire at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant that was crippled by the twin disasters could have released far more radioactivity into the environment.

The nuclear fuel in three of the plant's six reactors melted down and released radioactive plumes that contaminated land downwind. Japan declared 1100 square kilometers uninhabitable and relocated 88,000 people. (Almost as many left voluntarily.) After the meltdowns, officials feared that spent fuel stored in pools in the reactor halls would catch fire and send radioactive smoke across a much wider swath of eastern Japan, including Tokyo. 

By a stroke of luck, that did not happen.
But the national academies's report warns that spent fuel accumulating at U.S. nuclear plants is also vulnerable. After fuel is removed from a reactor core, the radioactive fission products continue to decay, generating heat. All nuclear power plants store the fuel onsite at the bottom of deep pools for at least 4 years while it slowly cools. To keep it safe, the academies report recommends that the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) and nuclear plant operators beef up systems for monitoring the pools and topping up water levels in case a facility is damaged. The panel also says plants should be ready to tighten security after a disaster.

At most U.S. nuclear plants, spent fuel is densely packed in pools, heightening the fire risk. NRC has estimated that a major fire at the spent fuel pool at the Peach Bottom nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania would displace an estimated 3.46 million people from 31,000 square kilometers of contaminated land, an area larger than New Jersey. But Von Hippel and Schoeppner think that NRC has grossly underestimated the scale and societal costs of such a fire.

NRC used a program called MACCS2 for modeling the dispersal and deposition of the radioactivity from a Peach Bottom fire. Schoeppner and Von Hippel instead used HYSPLIT, a program able to craft more sophisticated scenarios based on historical weather data for the whole region.
Nightmare scenarios
A simulated spent fuel fire at the Peach Bottom nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania had a devastating impact on the mid-Atlantic region. Click on the dates to see the extent of contamination, which depended on weather patterns. Courtesy of F. Von Hippel and M. Schoeppner  
1 Jan. 20151 April 20151 July 20151 Oct. 2015
In their simulations, the Princeton duo focused on Cs-137, a radioisotope with a 30-year half-life that has made large tracts around Chernobyl and Fukushima uninhabitable. They assumed a release of 1600 petabecquerels, which is the average amount of Cs-137 that NRC estimates would be released from a fire at a densely packed pool. It's also approximately 100 times the amount of Cs-137 spewed at Fukushima. They simulated such a release on the first day of each month in 2015.
The contamination from such a fire on U.S. soil "would be an unprecedented peacetime catastrophe," the Princeton researchers conclude in a paper to be submitted to the journal Science & Global Security. In a fire on 1 January 2015, with the winds blowing due east, the radioactive plume would sweep over Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and nearby cities. Shifting winds on 1 July 2015 would disperse Cs-137 in all directions, blanketing much of the heavily populated mid-Atlantic region. Averaged over 12 monthly calculations, the area exposed to more than 1 megabecquerel per square meter -- a level that would trigger a relocation order -- is 101,000 square kilometers. That's more than three times NRC's estimate, and the relocation of 18.1 million people is about five times NRC's estimates.
NRC has long mulled whether to compel the nuclear industry to move most of the cooled spent fuel now held in densely packed pools to concrete containers called dry casks. Such a move would reduce the consequences and likelihood of a spent fuel pool fire. As recently as 2013, NRC concluded that the projected benefits do not justify the roughly $4 billion cost of a wholesale transfer. But the national academies's study concludes that the benefits of expedited transfer to dry casks are fivefold greater than NRC has calculated.
"NRC's policies have underplayed the risk of a spent fuel fire," Lyman says. The academies panel recommends that NRC "assess the risks and potential benefits of expedited transfer." NRC spokesperson Scott Burnell in Washington, D.C., says that the commission's technical staff "will take an in-depth look" at the issue and report to NRC commissioners later this year.

Spent nuclear fuel rods in the United States are typically stored in pools of water at the power plants where they were used for a number of years to allow the most radioactive byproducts to decay. After this period, they are often transferred to dry cask storage on site.
The U.S. does not currently have a permanent repository for its commercial spent nuclear fuel. The Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository, which was intended to be the long-term storage solution for the country's spent nuclear fuel, was proposed in the 1980s and construction began in 1993. However, the project was halted in 2010 due to political and scientific concerns. As a result, the U.S. is currently facing a growing backlog of spent nuclear fuel that is being stored at power plants around the country! I did an undergrad paper on this about 40 years ago.  Ted Ringwood and others came up with synroc in the late '70s after learning that the fission products in the Oklo natural reactor in Gabon of about 2 bya had barely mirgrated in that time.  Its radioative loading is about 4-5x that of the best glasses with the advantages that they are stable at much higher temperatures and have porosity rates a couple of orders lower than the glasses.  Drill into an unfractured-by-glaciation granite pluton about 1 km below the Canadian shield, bury, backfill with self-healing bentonite clays and you're gtg for several million years.  The recoverable energy in Ontario's pools was worth about $300 B in '80s dollars by about 10 years ago and it would've cost about $5-10 B to do it all.  Still, a 30-60x payback can't cut it when it involves the transport of weapons-grade Pu through populated areas.  The French are so French ;-)
